breaking: Federal Compliance Office announces expanded operations in tri-county area through November

leadStory.title: Council Deadlocked on Compliance Cooperation Resolution
leadStory.author: Margaret Chen
paragraphs: A proposed resolution that would limit Millbrook city resources from being used in Federal Compliance Office operations failed to reach a vote Tuesday night after three hours of heated testimony from residents on both sides of the issue.

Council members Garcia and Thompson expressed support for the measure, while members Bradley and Kowalski argued it would put the city at risk of losing federal funding. Mayor Richardson has not indicated which way she would vote.
"This isn't about politics," said resident Ana Morales, who spoke during public comment. "This is about whether my neighbors can walk to the grocery store."

mainStories.title: AI Adoption Surges Among Local Small Businesses, But Workers Express Concerns
mainStories.author: David Park
mainStories.summary: Nearly 60% of Millbrook businesses with fewer than 50 employees now use some form of AI assistant, according to a new Chamber of Commerce survey—up from just 12% two years ago. But workers at several local companies say the technology is being used to monitor productivity and flag "anomalies" in ways that feel invasive.

mainStories.title: The Gathering on Mill Street Sees Record Attendance Amid Uncertainty
mainStories.author: Sarah Williams
mainStories.summary: Father Thomas Carroll says he's never seen the pews so full. "People are looking for community," he said after Sunday services that drew over 400 attendees—nearly double the usual number. The congregation has also quietly expanded its emergency assistance fund, though Carroll declined to discuss specifics.

mainStories.title: Workers' Collective Votes to Maintain Neutrality on Compliance Issues
mainStories.author: James Morrison
mainStories.summary: In a contentious meeting Saturday, members of Local 847 of the Workers' Collective voted 234-189 to maintain the union's official neutrality on immigration enforcement issues. The decision disappointed some members who had pushed for a solidarity resolution, while others argued the union should focus on workplace issues.

mainStories.title: City Watch Chief Addresses Confusion Over Federal Coordination
mainStories.author: Robert Torres
mainStories.summary: Police Chief Diana Oyelaran held a press conference Friday to clarify the department's relationship with federal agencies after social media posts claimed local officers were participating in FCO operations. "Our officers are focused on local public safety," Oyelaran said. "We are not conducting compliance enforcement." She declined to say whether the department shares information with federal agencies.
